Award.AwardTitle: A Model for Turbulence in Strongly Stratified Natural Flows

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
To improve the modeling of turbulence and mixing in strongly stratified natural flows such as lakes and oceans, the proposed work involves developing an analytical model based on rapid distortion theory (RDT). Although turbulence can be intense in parts of natural flows, strong stratification can reduce vertical transport and mixing in the interior of lakes and oceans. Turbulence models based on the Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) equations have provided useful predictions of stratified flows; however, they require adjustment to account for the interaction of internal waves and turbulence, and models that employ the gradient-transport assumption cannot predict upgradient fluxes, which can affect transport in strongly stratified flows significantly.

In contrast to RANS models, RDT is naturally suited for predicting turbulence in a strongly stratified flow. While the gradient-transport approximation works best for a stratified flow when the time scales of the turbulence are much smaller than the time scale of gravitational adjustment (i.e., weak stratification), RDT applies when the stratification is strong. Although RDT does not predict the vortex mode seen at large times in some studies, it has successfully predicted many features of strongly stratified flows, including upgradient fluxes and preferential transport of temperature in a heat-salt system. The proposed work exploits this success to elucidate the physics and improve the modeling of strongly stratified flows.

The objectives of the proposed work are to (1) apply RDT to homogeneous turbulence in strong stratification to determine (a) the mixing efficiency and its dependence on molecular diffusivity, (b) the effects of time-varying forcing in sheared and unsheared flows, and (c) the evolution of turbulence in a velocity and density field modeled after internal waves and (2) extend RDT to increase its relevance for natural flows by (a) applying it to a patch of turbulence with and without shear and (b) investigating the effect of moderate stratification and developing and testing a turbulence model based on RDT. Work for the first objective involves straightforward, though important, extensions of previous applications. Along with applying previous research on RDT for inhomogeneous turbulence to a stratified patch, work for the second objective involves relaxing the assumption of strong stratification by analytically evaluating the neglected nonlinear terms and adding a variable eddy diffusivity, which will be computed from the RDT solution, to extend the RDT to moderate stratification.

The intellectual merit of the proposed work stems from the success of RDT in reproducing key features of several stratified flows and the PI?s experience with RDT and mixing in stratified flows in general. The theoretical problems are designed to answer key questions for stratified flows (objective 1) as well as relax the assumptions behind RDT to increase its applicability objective 2). Results from this research are expected to complement current models of stratified flows and offer insights on how to improve them. The broader impacts include training a graduate student; involving undergraduates from Iowa State University's Program for Women in Science and Engineering in the research; conducting outreach to schools; continuing collaborations with Drs. Hideshi Hanazaki, Hidekatsu Yamazaki, and William Merryfield; and improving the parameterization of sub-grid scale processes in models of lakes and oceans. The last of these will be aided by collaborating with Dr. Merryfield, an ocean modeler.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although turbulence can be intense in parts of many natural flows, differences in fluid density--or stratification--caused by variations in temperature or salinity can reduce vertical transport and mixing in the interior of lakes and oceans. Many studies of mixing in limnology and oceanography assume the mixing efficiency of turbulence, which quantifies the ability of the turbulence to make the fluid unstratified, is constant, but laboratory experiments have shown that the efficiency depends on the stratification strength and the process generating the turbulence. When the flow is strongly stratified by both temperature and salinity, the efficiency can also depend on differential diffusion, a phenomenon in which temperature can be transported at a greater rate than salinity. This project aimed to increase understanding of transport in strongly stratified flows.

Standard turbulence models used in engineering and geophysics apply best for weakly stratified flows; they usually assume that the length and time scales of eddies of the turbulence are small compared to the length and time scales of the mean flow. However, in a flow with strong stratification, that assumption can fail because large differences in density cause displaced parcels of fluid to return quickly to their equilibrium positions. Because the eddies are rapidly distorted by gravitational forces, we applied an approach called rapid distortion theory (RDT), which has been used in many other flows, to predict the mixing efficiency of the turbulence. Although the assumptions behind RDT make it less accurate than direct numerical simulations (DNS) of turbulence, RDT can consider realistic values of parameters that have been out of the range of DNS. In particular, the Schmidt number Sc is 7 for heated water and 700 for saltwater, but computational costs have restricted many DNS to using a maximum value of 2.

The mixing efficiency predicted by RDT increases with Grashof number (which measures the strength of the stratification) up to a maximum value, as in numerical simulations and experiments. The maximum mixing efficiency of approximately 30% for low Sc is consistent with simulations, while the maximum efficiency of 6% for heated water is consistent with laboratory measurements. However, RDT underpredicts the maximum efficiency for saltwater. When the fluid is stratified with both temperature and salinity, the mixing efficiency depends on the density ratio, which compares the contributions of temperature and salinity to the density gradient. Because temperature can be transported at greater rates than salinity when the stratification is strong, the efficiency increeases as the density ratio increases--that is, the efficiency is larger when more of the stratification is due to temperature. These calculations show that results from numerical simulations with low Schmidt number likely overestimate the efficiency of turbulence--and therefore the transport--in strongly stratified flows in lakes and oceans.

This project also involved laboratory experiments to determine the interaction of differential diffusion and salt fingering, a phenomenon important in oceanography. The experiments used fluid stratified with a stable temperature distribution (warm water above cold water) and an unstable salinity distribution (salty water above fresher water), which can occur in mid-latitude oceans, where heating and evaporation are strong. In such a case, as long as the temperature differences are large enough to counteract the destabilizing effect of salinity (that is, the density ratio is greater than one), long convection cells called salt fingers can occur.
